I’ll use my fancy patter on the telephone

“patter” could either mean the repetitive motion and sound of typing someone’s phone number, or it could be referring to the UK slang for “talking esp. fluently, fast, meant to impress” usually referred to as flirting in today’s language.

https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/patter

After the bridge, we go into a guitar solo from Brian May. The guitar solo is not just one of Brian’s most melodic but also one of his most sophisticated arrangements with antiphonally alternating harmonies. Among the guitar harmonies, we can find simple inversion-changing ones and some tightly harmonized melodies, all these spiced with stereo imaging and with the sweet tone of his signature guitar, the Red Special. After the guitar solo, we break back into the third verse.

I’d like for you and I to go romancing
 Say the word, your wish
 Is my command

Freddie sings about equality within the relationship; they go ‘romancing’ each other in direct opposition to the traditional ‘man wooing woman’ setup. This could imply he’s singing about a more dominant lover or a male lover of his, especially considering how he gives over control in the second line.

Driving back in style
 In my saloon will do quite nicely
In British English, a saloon is an automobile having a closed body and a closed trunk separated from the part in which the driver and passengers sit; more popularly referred to as a sedan.

Freddie Mercury wrote this song for David Minns, a music publisher, and allegedly Freddie’s first male “lover” (that is, after the “romantic” stage of his love for Mary Austin, his then, or former, “common law” wife).

David later published a book called “This Was The Real Life”.





Does Minns confirm this in his book?  Not directly, but (allegedly) he does note he was the, uh, “inspiration” for one track from the album “A Day at the Races” allegedly, per Queenzone  aficionados.  And if Minns did so indeed, it still wouldn’t be a matter of confirmed fact.  Or would it?:

http://www.queenzone.com/forums/1265232/song-for-david-minns.aspx

Hey boy where do you get it from?
 Hey boy where did you go?

This line is sung by Mike Stone, who engineered the album. Stone is credited with “additional vocals” on the track.

When performed live, Freddie sang Stones' part.

Dining at the Ritz we’ll meet at nine
 (1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 o’clock) precisely

The Ritz London is a Grade II listed 5-star hotel located in Piccadilly in London, England. The restaurant can be claimed as the most beautiful restaurant in the world. The kitchen was run mainly by French chefs, and it had a specialist in Russian soups and Viennese pastry; its cakes became so famous that King Edward made regular orders from Buckingham Palace .The Ritz is renowned for its supreme catering service. If you want a table at the restaurant, it needs to be booked weeks in advance.
Be a Valentino, just for you

Rudolph Valentino was a silent film actor and considered the first Hollywood sex symbol.  After starring in the The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse in 1920, Valentino became an instant phenomenon and earned the moniker, the “Great Lover.”  His death from a ruptured ulcer at age 31 devastated his fans, leading to worldwide mourning and even suicide attempts.



Since his death, Valentino’s name has been used as a metaphor for a passionate lover or romantic – one could even say a “good-old fashioned lover boy.”

It’s also a call back to “Seaside Rendezvous” from A Night At The Opera, which contains the lyric: “I’ll be your Valentino”.
